system.description:
[Foundry Note: if the caster splits up multiple missiles between targets, apply the various damage ranges as missiles; i.e., if a caster has three missiles and sends two to Target A and one to Target B, apply the damage of 2d4+2 to Target A and 1d4+1 to Target B, etc.]

 

General

When this spell is cast, missiles of magical energy dart forth from the caster's fingertips, striking unerringly at his or her intended target(s), even if the target(s) are in melee or are partially concealed.

 

Combat Effects

The missiles inflict [[/roll 1d4+1]] points of damage each.

For every two caster levels beyond first, the caster gains an additional missile; thus, a first-level magic user can cast one missile, a third-level caster may cast 2, a fifth-level caster may cast 3, and so on.

actions.name: Magic Missile
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target an actor and click the  "Damage (? Missiles)" action corresponding to the number of missiles being sent against that actor
    • The caster can split up their total missiles between multiple targets, but will need to target actors and apply damage sequentially

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if you're reading this spell from the context of a 1st level player character casting it, you're not reading it in the context it was used in play in Lake Geneva 1970s campaigns. 

Although the spell is 1st level, it presumes a high level magic user is the caster (i.e., an NPC in town) and most of the restrictions are designed to both necessitate that NPC for low-level parties and thereafter put them incognito for some period after having identified an item - presumably for hire. 

While this interplay may seem foreign to those who've primarily played more-recently written RPGs, this dynamic was all part of intertwining the player characters in the wider urban world it was presumed they were an active participant in (when not delving a gigantic megadungeon, the entrance to level 1 being located approximately 1 hour away from the city) - Ed.]

 

General

This expensive and unreliable spell allows the magic user to discern the magical properties of an item. The magic user must hold or wear the item as intended for use (thereby placing himself at risk of a cursed item).

For every segment of the spell's duration, the magic user has a 15% +5%/caster level of gaining an insight into the nature of the item's enchantment.

Insights include:

  • magical effects (and the corresponding command word)
  • number of charges (plus or minus 25% of the actual number)

The exact bonus (or penalty) of a weapon is not revealed to the player, unless the GM chooses to do so for convenience; the character, of course, would not think of a magic sword as being "+1" or "+3," just as "enchanted" or "powerfully enchanted," and the spell reveals information in these terms.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell must be cast within 1 hour/caster level of the time a magic item first comes near the caster, or the magic user's own aura will have blended too much into the item's aura, contaminating his ability to read it.

Upon casting the spell, the magic user temporarily loses 8 points of constitution, and regains them by resting for one hour per recovered point. 

The material component for the spell is a pearl worth 100 gp.

actions.name: Identify
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the caster and click the  "Identify Con Penalty - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
General

This spell enchants a rope to become a portal into an extradimensional pocket of unreality opened by the spell. The rope rises in the air and then hangs, suspended by its connection to the extra-dimensional hideaway.

Up to six medium-size people can hide in the space (five, if the rope is to be pulled up and into the space as well). At the spell's expiration, the inhabitants or contents of the space will fall into normal reality if they have not already departed.

True reality is visible through the portal, but cannot be affected from within.

actions.name: Rope Trick
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the caster and click the "Rope Trick - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note:  the spell NPC "Green Vapor" can be used in conjunction with this spell.  If used in an environment of natural/day light, I suggest going into the token light tab and setting the contrast all the way left to -1 so it shows better on the map.  In night settings this usually isn't necessary. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell creates a nauseating cloud of vapours to billow forth in a location chosen by the caster.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

All creatures caught within (or later entering) the noxious cloud must make saving throws.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature failing to save will be completely unable to act for [[/roll 1d4+1]] rounds, falling to the ground retching and gagging (treated as stunned).

A creature that succeeds in making the saving throw may move from within the cloud and be free of the effects after only one round of gasping fresh air (again, being treated as stunned for this round).

Even creatures that succeed in making a saving throw cannot do anything within the cloud other than to leave as fast as possible.

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.qYHHBonZhUcKYdxv]{Green Vapor}

actions.name: Stinking Cloud
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • The player/GM can choose to use either the spell NPC or the castshape with the spell

 

Cast Shape

  • Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Stinking Cloud - Duration (C)" action

 

Spell NPC

  • When summoned, add @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.qYHHBonZhUcKYdxv]{Green Vapor} to the scene
  • toggle the Green Vapor token's visibility to "off"  and add it to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Apply the "Fog Cloud - Duration Autokill" effect to the Green Vapor token on the map

 

Combat Effects

  • Target all actors in the cloud AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger saving throws (this may already have been done)
  • For actors that fail their save, click the "Stunned 2-5 rds - Duration (T)" action
  • For actors that make their save, click the "Stunned 1 rd - Duration (T)" action 
    • actors making their save can take no action other than leaving the cloud or face further saving throws

system.description:
[Foundry Note: the GM will need to track halved number of attacks for slowed creatures manually, but four movement rate effects are provided which halve the common base move rates of 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if applicable. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell acts upon its targets to slow down their movements.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell may be cast upon up to 1 creature/caster level, but all must be within the spell's area of effect at the time of casting.

Haste and Slow automatically cancel each other without any shocks to the systems of those affected.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature affected by a Slow spell will find that it can only move at half normal speed and attack at half its normal rate.

If more than one Slow spell is cast upon the same subject, the effects of the two spells will be cumulative.

actions.name: Slow
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target chosen actors in the AOE and click the  movement action corresponding to the actor's current movement rate

system.description:
General

Cure light wounds allows the cleric to lay hands upon a wounded creature, restoring [[/roll 1d8]] hit points to the spell's beneficiary.

This spell does not heal disease, reattach limbs, or bring back the dead, nor can it add hit points beyond a character's normal number.

The reverse of this spell is Cause Light Wounds.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Non-corporeal creatures are not affected by this spell, nor are undead.

actions.name: Cure Light Wounds
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the actor to be healed
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (steps to this point may already have been done)
  • Click on the "Heal 1d8" action to apply it to the target actor

system.description:
General

The spell's area of effect is a circular area centred at the target point, which cannot be more than 60 ft from the cleric. 

The reverse of this spell is Curse.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Holy Water is required to cast the spell.

Any creatures already engaged in melee combat will not gain the spell's benefits. 

 

Combat Effects

This minor benison raises the morale and attack rolls of any creatures allied with the casting cleric by +1 or +5% as appropriate.

actions.name: Bless
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all friendly actors in the AOE and click the "Blessed - Duration (F)" action

  • Target all friendly actors in the AOE and click the "Blessed - Duration (F)" action

system.description:
General

A hold person spell completely immobilises up to three medium-sized or smaller persons for the spell's duration. 

Creatures affected by this spell include humans, demi-humans and humanoids. Ultimately, it is in the discretion of the GM to decide if a creature is considered a "person" for the purposes of this spell.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The cleric decides how many of his or her foes he or she will target with the spell:

  • If there is only one target, the saving throw is made at -2;
  • if two targets, each makes the saving throw at -1; 
  • if three targets, each makes its saving throw with no penalty.

If a magic item or spell operates partially to negate the effects of paralysis, failing the save will have the effect of a Slow spell rather than completely immobilising the target.

 

Combat Effects

[Another common houserule is that creatures may only be attacked at 2x rate, but not slain, if a battle is ongoing and the incapacitated person isn't otherwise isolated from allies. - Ed.]

Persons held by this spell may be killed or bound at a rate of one per round, or, if the attacker chooses, may be attacked at twice the normal rate with an automatic hit, for maximum damage.

actions.name: Hold Person (One Target)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the enemy actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)
  • if the saving throw fails click the  "Held - Duration (T)" action

actions.name: Hold Person (Two Targets)
actions.misc:

  • Target the enemy actors
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)
  • click the  "Held - Duration (T)" action (this should only apply to actors failing their saving throw)

system.description:
General

This spell is used to slow the progress of poison through the body. Even a person who has died from poison may be revived if he succumbed to the poison within a number of turns less than or equal to the caster's level of experience.

The spell does not eliminate or neutralise poison; it merely slows it.

The spell is generally used to keep someone alive until the poison can be neutralised completely by other means, such as a Neutralise Poison spell.

 

Combat Effects

A poisoned creature will lose 1 hit point per turn (but will not fall below 1) during the spell's duration; once the spell's protection expires, the victim will suffer the full potency of the poison.

actions.name: Slow Poison
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the poisoned actor and click the  "Slow Poison - Duration (T)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: there are five spell NPCs with the name "spiritual weapon" and noted as +1 through +5 respectively, although these are not "combat plusses" as the spell below details. 

When a cleric casts the spell, place the spell NPC on the board; the GM will need to move the NPC and roll dice for it. 

As the NPC attacks with whatever bonuses the cleric has - Strength or Dexterity, or whatever other bonuses as may be applicable - the spell NPC 's "stats" should be modified in these respects to match the cleric. 

Or perhaps bonuses can be added to the Spell NPC's "weapon" if the cleric has unusual bonuses not tied to attributes (such as a misc. magic item granting a bonus to all melee or thrown attacks, etc.) - Ed.]

 

General

To cast this spell, the cleric throws a real war hammer into the air, invoking the power of his or her god(s). The real hammer disappears, replaced with a mist-like shape of divine force that attacks at the cleric's will.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The cleric must concentrate upon maintaining it (limited, of course, to the duration of the spell).

 

Combat Effects

The hammer strikes as a magical weapon for purposes of affecting creatures hit only by magic weapons as if it were a +1 weapon, with an additional +1 per three levels of the caster above 3rd level, but it has no intrinsic bonus on rolls, either to hit or damage.

The spiritual weapon attacks as if it were wielded by the cleric, at the cleric's level and with any appropriate to hit and damage bonuses (or penalties) derived from the cleric, or other magic items which would modify a similar attack made by that cleric (i.e.,  Bracers of Mighty Throws, if such existed).

The weapon does base damage as a normal war hammer.

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.AwkbVAnrbL07kwsP]{Spiritual Weapon +1}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.Y8eINGyEwjLA9u3q]{Spiritual Weapon +2}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.OCrruaFGZHu8CJZh]{Spiritual Weapon +3}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.50zIglWpNN1A5I9I]{Spiritual Weapon +4}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.GAwxHrJLRw7HFU2a]{Spiritual Weapon +5}

actions.name: Spiritual Weapon
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • When summoned, add whichever spell NPC applies the level of the cleric casting the spell ( @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.AwkbVAnrbL07kwsP]{Spiritual Weapon +1}, @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.Y8eINGyEwjLA9u3q]{Spiritual Weapon +2}, @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.OCrruaFGZHu8CJZh]{Spiritual Weapon +3}, @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.50zIglWpNN1A5I9I]{Spiritual Weapon +4}, @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.GAwxHrJLRw7HFU2a]{Spiritual Weapon +5} ) to the scene
  • Add the Spiritual Weapon token to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Target the Spiritual Weapon token and then click on the "Spiritual Weapon - Duration Autokill" effect
  • The GM uses the token to make attacks as desired by the caster

system.description:
General

Upon completion of the ritual words of this spell, food and/or water will appear from thin air. A caster of fifth level can conjure up enough food and water to sustain a person or even a horse for five full days.

The volume of food and water produced by the spell is approximately one cubic ft per level of the caster.

biography.value: Traits: diplomatic, harsh, average intellect, jealous, very honorable, intellectualist, brave, energetic, spendthrift, normal morals, reverent piety, does community service, collects books & scrolls.

system.description:
Clerics are moral and spiritual leaders, warriors of faith who preach the will of the gods, interpret omens and portents, and strike down the evil or unfaithful. Most clerics have a patron deity, but some are champions of a particular moral alignment, venerating all deities of that alignment in addition to a patron deity, and yet others are the servants of a particular pantheon of deities. In a world of swords and sorcery, force of arms often speaks louder than moral suasion, and clerics are trained to do battle against the enemies of their gods. Some clerics are fanatics, zealously seeking new converts or hunting heretics. Others seem almost burdened by an inconvenient or even oppressive relationship with the divine forces. Evil clerics - sinister villains who prey upon fear and jealousy - sow discord in the world and gather converts for their demonic masters.

Clerics play an important support role for an adventuring party. Most clerical spells are oriented toward healing, strengthening, and defending others. However, when the need arises the cleric is fully capable of taking a place in the line of battle and smiting down infidels and foes. Clerics employ their holy symbols rather than spell books as a focus for their meditation. Cleric spells are automatically acquired as the cleric gains levels and no check is necessary to ensure they are understood; thus clerics may normally memorise any spell appropriate to their level. However, in some circumstances the powers the cleric serves may intervene and grant different spells to those requested; it is suggested that this is only done in extreme cases (such as when the cleric has been guilty of an alignment transgression of some kind, for example; more serious transgressions may result in fewer spells being granted, or even none at all). Some GMs may permit clerics of specific deities to have slightly different abilities from those described here.

When a cleric attains ninth level, he or she has accumulated sufficient divine favour and mortal renown to found a temple/stronghold. Such places are normally carved from the wilderness, in the same manner as a fighter establishes a freehold. For a cleric to assume the leadership of an existing temple, the details are left to the discretion of the GM; a level somewhat higher than ninth might be required. Whether the cleric estab-lishes a stronghold or a temple, followers and acolytes will flock to the cleric's banner.

Minimum Scores: Str 6, Dex 3, Con 6, Int 6, Wis 9, Cha 6

Hit Die Type: d8 (max 9)

Alignment: Any

Experience bonus: Wisdom 16+

Armour/Shield Permitted: Any

Weapons Permitted: Blunt only - club, flail, hammer, mace, oil, staff; clerics may hurl hammers, clubs, or oil, but may not employ other missile weapons

Weapon Proficiencies: 2 + 1 every 3 levels

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -3

Weapon Specialisation: N/A

Cleric Class Abilities

Spell Casting: Clerics may memorise and cast clerical spells in accordance with the tables provided hereafter.

Turning Undead: Clerics can "turn" the undead, making them flee from the cleric's holiness (or, in the case of an evil cleric, bringing them to heel as servants and minions). Because paladins are also capable of turning undead (though not with the same power as a cleric), rules for turning the undead are found later in this book rather than repeating them in the descriptions of both the paladin and cleric classes.

Bonus spells: These are awarded to clerics with high wisdom. They are not cumulative and are awarded by level; hence "2/2/1/1" means the cleric is granted 2 - 1st level, 2 - 2nd level, 1 - 3rd level, and 1 - 4th level bonus spells.

Wisdom Score Bonus Spells Chance of Spell Failure (d%)
9 0 15
10 0 10
11 0 5
12 0 1
13 1 0
14 2 0
15 2/1 0
16 2/2 0
17 2/2/1 0
18 2/2/1/1 0
19 3/2/1/1 0

When the clash of steel rings out in dark forests or dimly lit dungeons beneath the earth, it is the fighter who bears the brunt of the combat. Fighters are trained in the use of weapons and armour, usually beginning their adventuring careers after a stint of training as a town guardsman, soldier, man at arms, bandit, pirate, or mercenary.

Fighters are the backbone of an adventuring party; without them to hold the line, the other members of the party will be overrun before they can bring their own skills to bear. Fighters are the most powerful characters in melee or missile combat, whether on offence or defence. Together with the ranger and paladin, they have the most hit points, and their ability to survive the most brutal battles is therefore unrivalled.

They also have the best chance "to hit" of all the classes, particularly at higher level. They may use any kind of armour, shield, or weapon. Most fighters look forward to the day when their reputations will bring them into the ranks of the lesser nobility, where fighting prowess and armed followers are more important than high-flown bloodlines. It is no small matter to carve a freehold out of the wilderness, but to do so is to leave behind a legacy in a world where most fortune-seekers die an unsung death.

A fighter of 9th level or higher who has built a castle and cleared a wide area around it of monsters (at least a 20 mile radius), will attract a body of mercenaries to his or her service, provided that these are paid a fair wage. He or she will also be able to tax each freeholder, at up to the maximum rate of 1 gp per month per resident. Some players may choose to retire a character at this point, satisfied that the character has entered the historical records and legends of the campaign world. Others may choose to view the stronghold merely as the first step toward the pinnacles of mythic power. Such player-held castles and villages provide a higher-level party with a base for adventures, a stronghold against enemies, and possibly the introduction of feudal politics and war into their already-eventful lives.

Minimum Scores: Str 9, Dex 6, Con 7, Int 3, Wis 6, Cha 6

Hit Die Type: d10 (max 9 hit dice)

Alignment: Any

Experience bonus: Strength 16+

Armour/Shield Permitted: Any

Weapons Permitted: Any

Weapon Proficiencies: 4 + 1 every 2 levels

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -2

Weapon Specialisation: Optional

Fighter Class Abilities

Bonus Attacks: Fighters with melee weapons attack once per round at 1st to 6th levels (1/1 attacks); at 7th to 12th levels, they attack thrice every two rounds (3/2 attacks); and at 13th or higher levels they attack twice per round (2/1 attacks). A partial additional attack (e.g. 3/2 attacks) means that the extra attack is taken on odd-numbered rounds in the combat sequence, hence two attacks on the first round, one on the second, two on the third and one on the fourth, if applicable.

Fighting the Unskilled: When the fighter is attacking creatures with less than a full hit die (i.e. less than [[/roll 1d8]] hit points), the fighter receives one attack for each of his or her levels of experience, e.g. a 4th-level fighter attacking goblins would receive 4 attacks per round.

NB: A fighter exercising multiple attacks departs from the normal initiative procedure. The fighter will automatically attack first in the round unless fighting an opponent with multiple attacks of its own (in which case initiative should be rolled as normal). The fighter's second attack in any given melee round will come last in the sequence.

Weapon Specialisation (optional): With the permission of the GM, weapon specialisation may be selected during character generation. If weapon specialisation is not selected during character generation, it remains forever unavailable to the character, barring some magical or divine intervention. If weapon specialisation is in play, fighters may take a second proficiency in the same weapon as the first, granting them one extra attack every 2 rounds with the weapon (hence 3/2 attacks with a melee weapon at 1st level, 2/1 at 7th and 5/2 at 13th), +1 to hit and +2 damage owing to their skill. Specialisation costs one proficiency "slot" for melee weapons and crossbows, and two "slots" for missile weapons other than crossbows

Double Specialisation (optional): For melee weapons that are not polearms or two-handed swords, a third weapon proficiency may be used to specialise further; this increases combat bonuses to +3 to hit and +3 damage with the weapon.

Optional Rule: Where a fighter of extremely high level or with many bonuses "to hit" actually requires a negative score to hit his or her target, then at the GM's option, the negative score may be converted to a positive and applied as additional damage to the automatic hit. Thus, for example, a 20th level fighter with 19 strength and a +5 sword attacking an AC 2 dragon would require a roll of -8 to hit it; the character would be allowed to modify his or her damage roll by +8.

Magic users are a rare breed - practitioners of the mysterious art of arcane spell casting. A lengthy apprenticeship of study and practice allows these somewhat eerie individuals to store arcane energy within their minds and to release it in the form of spells. Magic users cast spells by speaking a few magic words, weaving complex gestures in the air, and employing rare and magical materials. While magic users (with illusionists) are the weakest character class in combat, this weakness is balanced by possessing the most powerful and versatile spells in the game.

The full underlying principles of magic are beyond mortal comprehension; even wizards of the profoundest intellect struggle from momentary inklings to understand its more complex patterns. Nevertheless, those character who possess formidable intelligence and a certain intuitive gift, who are willing to devote themselves to a lifetime of study, may in time sufficiently master the art to be capable of shifting mountains and shattering entire armies. High-level magic users are the most feared and dangerous characters in the game.

Magic users do not gain bonus spells for high intelligence scores; intelligence does determine which spells they can understand and how many spells they may learn for each spell level.

Magic users are dependent upon their spell books, and normally may only cast spell they have learned from these books (exception: magic users may cast spells from arcane magical scrolls). Mages may not cast spells from divine, druidic or phantasmal magic scrolls. The acquisition of a new spell is difficult and demanding and must normally be accomplished through adventuring, although the mage will automatically receive one new spell of the highest spell level that he or she may cast upon acquiring a new level of experience.

OSRIC magic users are superficially similar to the wizards of fantasy literature such as Gandalf and Merlin, but they are more closely similar to mages described in the works of Jack Vance. His "Dying Earth" cycle, and particularly "Rhialto the Marvellous", are highly recommended.

Magic users are the only class capable of fabricating magic items that they cannot themselves employ. Clerics, druids and illusionists can fabricate magic items, but only those they themselves can use; items such as magical swords, that no primary spell casting class may use, are in their creation the sole province of magic users.

At 11th level, a magic user may establish a stronghold (usually a tower or small keep) in the same manner as a fighter.

Minimum Scores: Str 3, Dex 6, Int 9, Wis 6,Con 6, Cha 6

Hit Die Type: d4 (max 11)

Alignment: Any

Experience bonus: Int 16+

Armour/Shield Permitted: None

Weapons Permitted: Dagger, dart, oil, staff

Weapon Proficiencies: 1 + 1 per 5 levels

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -5

Weapon Specialisation: N/A

Magic User Class Abilities

Spellcasting: Magic users may memorise and cast arcane spells in accordance with the tables provided below. A beginning magic user character will know four spells. One of these will automatically be Read Magic. The second spell should be chosen by the player from the list of first level spells, and the last two should be determined randomly from the list of first level spells.

Eldritch Craft (7th): Mages of 7th or higher level may create magical potions, scribe arcane scrolls (of spells that he or she already knows) and recharge magical rods, staves and wands. This process should be overseen by the GM, who must take care to ensure that it is not too easy! A long list of ingredients will always be required, some of which should be expensive, and others of which should be a challenge to acquire.

Eldritch Power (12th): Magic users of 12th level or higher may attempt to create other magical items by means of the enchant an item spell. However, this is even more difficult than creating a potion or scroll, and the various components required should be of a rarity and value appropriate to the magic item under consideration. Even then, success will not be guaranteed.

It is possible for elves and humans to interbreed, although elven fastidiousness makes this a fairly uncommon occurrence. Half elves do not have a separate culture or civilisation of their own, usually assimilating into the elven or human society in which they were raised.

Summary of Half-Elven Racial Abilities

  • 30% resistance to sleep and charm spells

Secret doors: When searching, a half-elf character can detect secret doors on a 2 in 6 and concealed doors on a 3 in 6. When passing within 10ft of a concealed door, a half-elf will notice it on a 1 in 6.

Languages: Common, elven, gnoll, gnome, goblin, halfling, hobgoblin, orcish.

Multi-class restrictions: The less restrictive of any class requirements apply to multi-classed half-elven characters, except that thieving abilities can only be used while wearing armour permitted to thieves.

Permitted Class Options: Assassin, Cleric, Fighter, Magic user, Ranger, Thief, Cleric/Fighter, Cleric/Ranger, Cleric/Magic user, Fighter/Magic user, Fighter/Thief, Magic user/Thief, Cleric/Fighter/ Magic user, or Fighter/Magic user/Thief.

Infravision: 60 ft

Movement Rate: 120 ft

system.description: 30% resistance to sleep and charm spells

Thieves and assassins have an enhanced chance to hear noise as they gain levels (see “thief skills” in Chapter I). Characters of all other classes have a base 10% chance. This should be modified by race; elves, gnomes, halflings, and half-orcs have a base 15% chance.  (In Foundry, these races have a 5% bonus added to their skill check target number automatically when the skill is used- Ed.)

 

Hear - Base Chance/Target Formula

Assassin Thief
Level  Target Range Level Target Range
1 10% 1 10%
2 10% 2 13%
3 10% 3 16%
4 13% 4 19%
5 16% 5 22%
6 19% 6 25%
7 22% 7 28%
8 25% 8 31%
9 28% 9 34%
10 31% 10 37%
11 34% 11 40%
12 37% 12 43%
13 40% 13 46%
14 43% 14 49%
15 46% 15 52%
    16 55%
    17 58%
    18 61%
    19 64%
    20 67%
    21 70%
    22 73%
    23 76%
    24 79%

 

Normally the GM rolls this die in secret, because the player has no way of knowing whether no noise was heard because of the roll or because there was no noise to hear. A character who fails (or thinks he or she has failed) to hear noise may try again, each attempt taking one round. However, no more than three attempts may be made the same character before the strain becomes too great and no further listening attempts will succeed until the character has rested for at least one turn.

If the check is successful, the GM should decide whether there is in fact any noise to be heard. Some monsters, such as bugbears, are stealthy and cannot be detected by listening. However, generally if there is some monster in the area and a “hear noise” check is passed, the party should gain some clue about what it is. Clever players whose characters speak various monster languages may gain valuable information from overhearing snatches of conversation—but the GM should be careful only to describe what characters can actually hear. So the GM would not normally say “you hear a giant spider,” but rather “you hear a scuttling, rattling sound” as the creature climbs to a suitable spot from which to ambush the party.

Don’t forget, monsters can hear the party in the same way as the party can hear them!
system.dmonlytext:
Listening for noise as often as possible, at every door and intersection, is an understandably common tactic, because it’s one of the easiest ways for players to improve the odds in their favour — so as to be able to make better-informed decisions about their actions. This is fine in moderation. However, if the pace of play slows considerably, diminishing the excitement and reducing the adventure to dice-rolling, the GM should discourage the players from endless listening attempts. Emphasise the inconvenience of donning and doffing helmets and headgear while the rest of the party stands around doing nothing; and if play is still slow, employ tricks that circumvent listening, e.g. silent monsters or phantom noises (perhaps due to strange acoustics in the dungeon or magic). In extreme cases the GM can place traps and monsters that specifically target listening characters, but before it gets to that, the GM should speak frankly to the players and explain that while some degree of caution is good play, carrying things to extremes only makes the game less fun.

Balance this against the lethality of the dungeon. In extremely dangerous areas, the players should not be punished for taking due care.

Where a fighter of extremely high level or with many bonuses "to hit" actually requires a negative score to hit his or her target, then at the GM's option, the negative score may be converted to a positive and applied as additional damage to the automatic hit. Thus, for example, a 20th level fighter with 19 strength and a +5 sword attacking an AC 2 dragon would require a roll of -8 to hit it; the character would be allowed to modify his or her damage roll by +8.

When the fighter is attacking creatures with less than a full hit die (i.e. less than 1d8 hit points), the fighter receives one attack for each of his or her levels of experience, e.g. a 4th-level fighter attacking goblins would receive 4 attacks per round.

Auto-created for Sword, Long

General

This spell affects a circular area with a 15 ft radius. A number of creatures within this radius (determined by their HD) fall into a deep magical slumber. 

A sleeping creature requires a full round to waken and must be shaken or slapped to bring it to consciousness; mere noise, however loud, will not disturb the enchanted slumber of a sleep spell's victim.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

[Elves and half-elves are 90% and 30% resistant to this spell, respectively, and it doesn't affect many magical or non-biological creatures. However, no saving throws are allowed for more standard creatures without a specific immunity.]

Creatures with hit dice over 4+4 are not affected by the spell.

 

Combat Effects

[Another common houserule is that creatures may only be attacked at 2x rate, but not slain, if a battle is ongoing and the sleeping person isn't otherwise isolated from allies. - Ed.]

Magically sleeping creatures may be killed or tied up at a rate of one per round by a single person, or can be attacked at twice the normal rate with an automatic hit for maximum damage, if the attacker chooses not to kill or bind them.

The number of enemies affected by the spell is a function of their hit dice. If there are creatures of different hit dice in the area, the weaker ones will be affected first.

system.description:
[Foundry Note:

  1. a second casting and effect is given for castings that aren't attacks, so that the spell can be cast as an AOE without targeting someone; and
  2. A spell NPC  - "Light (Ball), Fixed Location (Full AOE)" is provided for those times when an actor desires to cast Light at range to illuminate a specific area.  Drop the NPC at the desired location and turn on the effect; and
  3. lastly, two ways to use the spell as an attack are given. 

    STATUS blind" differs primarily in that it blacks out the map entirely for the affected token.  However, it also removes all possibility of targeting a creature, however, so any penalized attacks launched by the blinded creature must be manually resolved. 

    A separate effect containing the same penalties is also provided, along with vision limited to a very tight radius, simulating sensing something nearby, even while unable to see it, sufficient to target it through the automated combat system.  Use whichever meets your preferences.

     - Ed.]

 

General

The light spell creates a globe of light 20 ft in radius, centred upon whatever spot or object the caster indicates at the time of casting (including a location in thin air). The caster may extinguish the magical light at any time.

The light spell remains stationary if it was not originally cast upon a movable object or creature (in which case the target will bring the illumination with it as it moves).

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.jekqOOyasLlM6Kd9]{Light 20 ft rad (Ball), Fixed AOE}

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the spell is cast upon a living creature, the creature is entitled to a saving throw (success indicating that the spell affects the area just behind the creature).

Magical darkness may be cast directly at magical light, to negate/dispel it through cancellation of both.

 

Combat Effects

A Light spell cast upon a creature's eyes will blind it for the spell's duration, causing it a penalty of -4 on all saving throws and rolls to hit if sight is its primary sense. 

[Additionally, those attacking someone blinded (who aren't blinded themselves) attack at a +4 bonus. - Ed]

actions.name: Light (AOE, 20 ft rad)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions (AOE Cast)

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the actor who'll carry the Light (usually the caster but not always)
  • Apply the  "Carried Light - Duration (T)" action to the target actor

 

IF USING THE SPELL AS A FREE-STANDING SPHERE OF LIGHT (ALTERNATE INSTRUCTIONS)

 

  • When summoned, add @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.jekqOOyasLlM6Kd9]{Light 20 ft rad (Ball), Fixed AOE} to the scene 
  • Add it to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Apply the  "Light-as-AOE - Duration Autokill" action to the Light 20 ft rad (Ball) token on the map

actions.name: Light (Attack, 20 ft rad)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Ask your GM which of the two blindess versions they're using in their campaign (see description for differences)
  • Target the (presumably) enemy actor the caster intends to center the spell effect upon
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done).
  • If the target actor makes their save, the light still occurs - it's just not centered upon them and no blindness occurs; drop a @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.jekqOOyasLlM6Kd9]{Light 20 ft rad (Ball), Fixed AOE} spell actor in their area (which they may move away from)
  • If the target actor fails their save click either the  "Blinded - Duration (T)" action or the  "STATUS Blind - Duration (T)" action to apply it to the targeted actor (this moves with the actor for the duration)
    • Actors incidentally in the AOE aren't blinded, only the spell target

system.dmonlytext: Some specially-made bows (sold at special cost if at all—GM's discretion) permit the user to add his or her strength bonus to damage inflicted with the weapon. Otherwise the strength damage bonus with missile weapons is restricted to hurled weapons (axes, hammers, clubs, darts, javelins and spears).

system.description:
General

Read Magic is normally the first spell in every magic user's spell book, and its mastery is the first task of every apprentice. The spell allows the caster to read magical writings (other than his or her own, of course, which are always intelligible to the original author).

Unless the writings are cursed, reading magical script does not normally activate the magic formulae described therein - reviewing a scroll prior to casting from it does not, for instance, actually cast whatever spell is written upon the scroll.

Once the magic user has read a particular set of magical inscriptions by use of this spell, the spell is no longer needed to re-read the writing at a later time.

The reverse of the spell is Indecipherable Magic.

actions.name: Read Magic
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Read Magic - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule to grant an additional benefit to the magic user if gaining a "normal" familiar, such as a toad.  This benefit should be minor but useful, such as a vision field similar to the animal's which may be employed at caster discretion.  A GM can determine the exact benefit if they wish to employ the house rule. - Ed.]

 

General

Magic users of higher level often summon familiars to assist them with various tasks. Indeed, a familiar can also be of considerable benefit to a lower level magic user (even increasing others' estimation of his or her power), but the risks inherent in losing a familiar can be daunting to a weaker spell caster.

The caster must maintain his or her casting for as long as necessary ([[/roll 2d12]] hours) until a familiar arrives (or the casting time expires without success).

If a "special familiar" is rolled, the type appearing depends upon the magic user's alignment:

  • Lawful good or Lawful neutral: Brownie
  • Chaotic good, Neutral good, or Neutral: Pseudo-dragon
  • Lawful evil or Neutral evil: Imp
  • Chaotic evil or Chaotic Neutral: Quasit

 

Saves and Other Impediments

To summon a familiar, the magic user must intone the words of the spell over a well-stocked fire source, sprinkling the flames with expensive incense and powders (100 gp in total value).

The spell may be attempted only once per year, and the caster has no control over the type of animal that will respond.

If a special familiar is rolled, it's entitled to a saving throw in order to avoid the effect of the spell.  Normal familiars receive no saving throw.

 

Combat Effects

When it arrives, the familiar is a faithful servant and ally to the caster. Normal familiars have [[/roll 1d3+1]] hit points, are AC 7, and are as intelligent as a lower-than-average human.

When the familiar is within 120 ft of the magic user, the magic user gains additional hit points equal to the familiar's.

However, if the familiar is ever killed, the magic user permanently loses twice the familiar's hit points.

system.description:
[Foundry Note:

1) there isn't a way to differentiate/automate hurled weapons from bows, etc.  So the lowest base AC automated by the spell is "3" instead of "2".  If a thrown weapon attack (dagger, spear, etc.) is made vs a token having an active shield spell, an additional penalty of -1 should be manually applied to the attack.

2) to mimic the immunity to Magic Missile, an unbundled effect providing immunity to force damage is included. However, the GM should be aware applying this optional effect will protect the caster from all force damage instead of only magic missile damage - the GM will need to manually apply force damage from other sources for the duration of the spell.  Other sources are typically rarer than the ubiquitous magic missile, however.

-Ed.]

[Foundry Beta Note: currently AC effects from spells are inconsistent if the target is wearing anything the system already perceives as armour (this includes such items as bracers of armour).  While the shield spell should work if used by a magic user having no other form of armour, if cast by a MU wearing (for example) bracers of armour +2, the effect may need to be changed from DOWNGRADE 3 or 4 to ADD -4 or -5.  Or the GM can simply ignore any hits that wouldn't be successful against the AC the caster should have. - Ed.]

 

General

By means of this spell, the caster creates an invisible barrier of magical force.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The shield is a frontal defence and grants no benefits against attacks from behind or from the rear flanks.

 

Combat Effects

Magic Missiles cannot penetrate the barrier at all.

The magic user gains an armour class of:

  • AC 2 against any hurled weapon,
  • AC 3 against propelled weapons such as arrows, and
  • AC 4 against all other attacks.

 

All saving throws against frontal attacks (by wands, dragon breath, etc.) are made at +1 during the spell's duration.

actions.name: Shield
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Shield - Duration (C)" action
    • (Optional) also click the "Force Dmg Immunity - Duration (C)" action, but be forewarned this is not Magic Missile-specific, and will make the caster immune to all force damage (the GM can manually apply instead)

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if the caster splits up multiple missiles between targets, apply the various damage ranges as missiles; i.e., if a caster has three missiles and sends two to Target A and one to Target B, apply the damage of 2d4+2 to Target A and 1d4+1 to Target B, etc.]

 

General

When this spell is cast, missiles of magical energy dart forth from the caster's fingertips, striking unerringly at his or her intended target(s), even if the target(s) are in melee or are partially concealed.

 

Combat Effects

The missiles inflict [[/roll 1d4+1]] points of damage each.

For every two caster levels beyond first, the caster gains an additional missile; thus, a first-level magic user can cast one missile, a third-level caster may cast 2, a fifth-level caster may cast 3, and so on.

actions.name: Magic Missile
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target an actor and click the  "Damage (? Missiles)" action corresponding to the number of missiles being sent against that actor
    • The caster can split up their total missiles between multiple targets, but will need to target actors and apply damage sequentially

General

This spell enchants a rope to become a portal into an extradimensional pocket of unreality opened by the spell. The rope rises in the air and then hangs, suspended by its connection to the extra-dimensional hideaway.

Up to six medium-size people can hide in the space (five, if the rope is to be pulled up and into the space as well). At the spell's expiration, the inhabitants or contents of the space will fall into normal reality if they have not already departed.

True reality is visible through the portal, but cannot be affected from within.

system.description:
The robe is very long, fully 7 feet, but

by use of the black cord belt each has, the hem can be

adjusted so as to just sweep the ground. The sleeves are

so long as to reach at least 1’ below the hands of even a

long-armed man. With each robe is a long, pointed hood

whose front and back points reach well down on the

wearer’s torso, and whose sides cover the shoulders. The

pointed front and back pieces are decorated with inverted,

two-tiered black pyramids. Each hood has narrow,

slanting eye holes. The pointed top extends a foot or

more above the crown of the wearer’s head.

[Foundry Note: if you're reading this spell from the context of a 1st level player character casting it, you're not reading it in the context it was used in play in Lake Geneva 1970s campaigns. 

Although the spell is 1st level, it presumes a high level magic user is the caster (i.e., an NPC in town) and most of the restrictions are designed to both necessitate that NPC for low-level parties and thereafter put them incognito for some period after having identified an item - presumably for hire. 

While this interplay may seem foreign to those who've primarily played more-recently written RPGs, this dynamic was all part of intertwining the player characters in the wider urban world it was presumed they were an active participant in (when not delving a gigantic megadungeon, the entrance to level 1 being located approximately 1 hour away from the city) - Ed.]

 

General

This expensive and unreliable spell allows the magic user to discern the magical properties of an item. The magic user must hold or wear the item as intended for use (thereby placing himself at risk of a cursed item).

For every segment of the spell's duration, the magic user has a 15% +5%/caster level of gaining an insight into the nature of the item's enchantment.

Insights include:

  • magical effects (and the corresponding command word)
  • number of charges (plus or minus 25% of the actual number)

The exact bonus (or penalty) of a weapon is not revealed to the player, unless the GM chooses to do so for convenience; the character, of course, would not think of a magic sword as being "+1" or "+3," just as "enchanted" or "powerfully enchanted," and the spell reveals information in these terms.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell must be cast within 1 hour/caster level of the time a magic item first comes near the caster, or the magic user's own aura will have blended too much into the item's aura, contaminating his ability to read it.

Upon casting the spell, the magic user temporarily loses 8 points of constitution, and regains them by resting for one hour per recovered point. 

The material component for the spell is a pearl worth 100 gp.

actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the caster and click the  "Identify Con Penalty - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note:  the spell NPC "Green Vapor" can be used in conjunction with this spell.  If used in an environment of natural/day light, I suggest going into the token light tab and setting the contrast all the way left to -1 so it shows better on the map.  In night settings this usually isn't necessary. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell creates a nauseating cloud of vapours to billow forth in a location chosen by the caster.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

All creatures caught within (or later entering) the noxious cloud must make saving throws.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature failing to save will be completely unable to act for [[/roll 1d4+1]] rounds, falling to the ground retching and gagging (treated as stunned).

A creature that succeeds in making the saving throw may move from within the cloud and be free of the effects after only one round of gasping fresh air (again, being treated as stunned for this round).

Even creatures that succeed in making a saving throw cannot do anything within the cloud other than to leave as fast as possible.

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.qYHHBonZhUcKYdxv]{Green Vapor}

actions.name: Stinking Cloud
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • The player/GM can choose to use either the spell NPC or the castshape with the spell

 

Cast Shape

  • Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Stinking Cloud - Duration (C)" action

 

Spell NPC

  • When summoned, add @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.qYHHBonZhUcKYdxv]{Green Vapor} to the scene
  • toggle the Green Vapor token's visibility to "off"  and add it to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Apply the "Fog Cloud - Duration Autokill" effect to the Green Vapor token on the map

 

Combat Effects

  • Target all actors in the cloud AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger saving throws (this may already have been done)
  • For actors that fail their save, click the "Stunned 2-5 rds - Duration (T)" action
  • For actors that make their save, click the "Stunned 1 rd - Duration (T)" action 
    • actors making their save can take no action other than leaving the cloud or face further saving throws

A creature that succeeds in making the saving throw may move from within the cloud and be free of the effects after only one round of gasping fresh air (again, being treated as stunned for this round).

Even creatures that succeed in making a saving throw cannot do anything within the cloud other than to leave as fast as possible.

actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • The player/GM can choose to use either the spell NPC or the castshape with the spell

 

Cast Shape

  • Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Stinking Cloud - Duration (C)" action

 

Spell NPC

  • toggle the Green Vapor token's visibility to "off"  and add it to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Apply the "Fog Cloud - Duration Autokill" effect to the Green Vapor token on the map

  • Target all actors in the cloud AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger saving throws (this may already have been done)
  • For actors that fail their save, click the "Stunned 2-5 rds - Duration (T)" action
  • For actors that make their save, click the "Stunned 1 rd - Duration (T)" action

system.description:
Survival: This proficiency must be
applied to a specific environment, i.e., a
specific type of terrain and weather factors.
Typical environmentsinclude arctic, wood-
land, desert, steppe, mountain, or tropical.
The character has basic survival knowledge
for that terrain type. Additional proficiency
slots can be used to add more types of ter-
rain.
A character skilled in survival has a basic
knowledge of the hazards he might face in

that land. He understands the effects of the
weather and knows the proper steps to
lessen the risk of exposure. He knows the
methods to locate or gather drinkabie
water. He knows how to find basic, not nec-
essarily appetizing, food where none is
apparent, thus staving off starvation. Fur-
thermore, a character with survival skill can
instruct and aid others in the same situation.
When using the proficiency to find food or
water, the character must roll a proficiency
check. If the check is failed, no more
attempts can be made that day.
The survival skill in no way releases the
player characters from the hardship and
horrors of being lost in the wilderness. At
best it alleviates a small portion of the suf-
fering. The food found is barely adequate,
and water is, discovered in miniscule
amounts. It is still quite possible for a char-
acter with survival knowledge to die in the
wilderness. Indeed, the little knowledge the
character has may lead to overconfidence
and doom!

ReadinglWriting: The character can read
and write a modern language he can speak,
provided there is someone available to teach
the character (another PC, a hireling, or an
NPC).This proficiency does not enable the
character to learn ancient languages (see
Languages, Ancient).

The robe is very long, fully 7 feet, but

by use of the black cord belt each has, the hem can be

adjusted so as to just sweep the ground. The sleeves are

so long as to reach at least 1’ below the hands of even a

long-armed man. With each robe is a long, pointed hood

whose front and back points reach well down on the

wearer’s torso, and whose sides cover the shoulders. The

pointed front and back pieces are decorated with inverted,

two-tiered black pyramids. Each hood has narrow,

slanting eye holes. The pointed top extends a foot or

more above the crown of the wearer’s head.

[Foundry Note: passive effects which upgrade bonuses may be toggled on/off when facing creatures of an appropriate type.  These are additive, so an upgrade to a total of "+2" will show as a series of "+1" adjustments. If a creature qualifies as more than one type, and so would have multiple categories of bonuses applied, only the highest bonus should be used with the others toggled off. - Ed.]  

 

Allowed Classes

AFPRT

 

Details

The blade of this weapon bursts into flame when its command word is spoken, giving illumination as a torch. The sword does not otherwise glow as most other magic swords do.

The flame tongue's fiery blade can easily ignite materials similar to:

  • paper
  • oil
  • kindling
  • webs
  • dry wood

The sword is normally +1, but its bonus increases in certain situations.  The sword gives:

  • a +2 as a trollbane does (vs those that regenerate)
  • a +3 bonus against creatures that are inflammable, bird-like or have a special attack involving cold
  • a +4 against undead

These bonuses do not stack; only the highest bonus should be counted. (Thus, if attacking a skeletal roc, the sword is +4 not +7.)

[Foundry Note: as multiple functions can incur charges against the wand's overall pool, charges are tracked on the Attributes tab with each action set to "powered item".  After the wand is placed into an actor's gear list, this will require the wand to be set as the "inventory item" within these wand actions' castings that the charges are drawn from. 

Now for WoW specific notes...

  1. Not every wand function has an associated/automated effect and instead are cosmetic or DM fiat (example - target turns blue, etc.)
  2. In some cases information missing from the wand description is supplied from the associated spell as per the wand standard of a 6th level caster
  3. Some wand effects are from spells that don't have a range but the wand description implies a range when produced by the wand...without providing one (example - ESP, Vanish). In these cases an editorial decision to suggest 60 ft was made.
  4. In other cases the wand description implies if a chosen target is out of range for that effect, nothing happens (example - Enlarge/Reduce)
  5. In yet other cases the wand implies that the effect happens at a set distance regardless of who was targeted and how far away they were (example - leaf growth, Petrification)
  6. Lastly, some effects imply they happen at the end of the range whether or not the desired target is within the range (example - fireball, lightning bolt)
  7. Just use your best judgement and let it roll - it's a chaos item anyway

- Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

[Foundry Note: many spell descriptions are lengthy; the user is directed to the wand action(s) for most spell descriptions. - Ed.]

[Foundry Note: The spell dmg in Foundry approximates the instruction to "make 1s into 2s" by changing the damage to 5d6+6 - Ed.] 

A wand of wonder is a strange and unpredictable device that randomly generates any number of weird effects each time it is used. Each use costs 1 charge.

In some cases a saving throw is appropriate. The effects should be considered typical of those possible, but the GM may adjust these or create new effects depending on the situation. Typical powers of the wand include the following:

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.hOsKWRNXo7QCbWlQ]{Wands - Wand of Wonder Result}

 

d% Wondrous Effect
01-05 Slow creature pointed at for 1 turn. [Range 150 ft]
06-10 Faerie Fire surrounds the target. [Range 80 ft]
11-15 Deludes wielder for 1 round into believing the rod functions as indicated by a second die roll (no save).
16-20 Gust of Wind, but at twice the power.
21-25 Wielder learns target's surface thoughts (as with ESP) for [[/roll 1d4]] rounds. [No range given when cast from WOW; suggest 60 ft]
26-30 Stinking Cloud at 30 ft range. [AOE 20 ft radius spherical cloud]
31-33 Heavy rain falls for 1 round in 60 ft radius centred on wand wielder.
34-36 Summon an animal - a rhino (01-25), elephant (26-50), or mouse (51-00).
37-46 Lightning Bolt (70-ft long, 5-ft wide), [[/roll 6d6]] damage. [Range: 100 ft]
47-49 Stream of 600 large butterflies pours forth and flutters around for 2 rounds, blinding everyone (including wielder).
50-53 Enlarge victim if within 60 ft of wand.
54-58 Darkness, 30 ft diameter hemisphere, centred 30-ft away from wand.
59-62 Grass grows in 160 ft square area before the wand, or grass existing there grows to ten times normal size.
63-65 Vanish any nonliving object of up to 1,000 lb mass and up to 30 ft cubed in size. [Range: 60 ft]
66-69 Reduce wielder to 1/12 height.
70-79 Fireball, [[/roll 6d6]] damage, as wand.
80-84 Invisibility covers wand wielder.
85-87 Leaves grow from target if within 60 ft of wand.
88-90 10-40 gems, value 1 gp each, shoot forth in a 30 ft long stream. Each gem deals 1 point of damage to any creature in its path: roll [[/roll 5d4]] for the number of hits.
91-95 Shimmering colours dance and play over a 40 ft×30 ft area in front of wand. Creatures therein are blinded for [[/roll 1d6]] rounds.
96-97 Wielder (50% chance) or target (50% chance) turns permanently blue, green, or purple.
98-00 Flesh to Stone (or Stone to Flesh if target is stone already) if target is within 60 ft.
system.dmonlytext:
XP/GP Value

GPV: 10,000gp (100 charges);

When Found: 10 EXP and 100 GPV per charge remaining

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.QGJZOx3hG6XYTCjE]{Wands - Charges remaining when found}

 

General (Wand)

For the purposes of calculating duration, damage, range, and other effects, wands function as if a character of 6th level produces their magical effects.

Some small percentage of wands, at the GM's discretion, are cursed to either direct their effects at the user or produce some other misleading or harmful effect.

actions.name: (01-05) Slow - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 3

Cast Time: 1

Range: 150 ft

Duration: 9 rounds

Save: None

AOE: 1 creature

Components: V

 

[Foundry Note: the GM will need to track halved number of attacks for slowed creatures manually, but four movement rate effects are provided which halve the common base move rates of 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if applicable. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell acts upon its targets to slow down their movements.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell may be cast upon 1 creature.

Haste and Slow automatically cancel each other without any shocks to the systems of those affected.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature affected by a Slow spell will find that it can only move at half normal speed and attack at half its normal rate.

If more than one Slow spell is cast upon the same subject, the effects of the two spells will be cumulative.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the chosen actor and click the  movement action corresponding to the actor's current movement rate

actions.name: (06-10) Faerie Fire - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Divine

School: Transmutation, Alteration

Sphere: Druidic

Level: 1

Cast Time: 1

Range: 80 ft

Duration: 24 rounds

Save: None

AOE: 1 creature

Components: V

 

General

The druid uses this spell to ignite a fiery-looking aura of bright light around his or her enemies. The aura is visible at a range of 80 ft if the observer stands in darkness, and at 40 ft if he or she stands near another light source.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

There isn't any saving throw against the spell's effects.

 

Combat Effects

The light itself is harmless, but a creature limned with faerie fire is easier to hit; any attacks against it are made with a bonus of +2.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have occurred)
  • Target the caster's selection of actors in the AOE and click the  "Faerie Fire - Duration (T)" action to apply the light effect to the selected actors

actions.name: (16-20) Gust of Wind - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 3

Cast Time: 3

Range: Caster

Duration: 1 segment

Save: None

AOE: 20 ft wide path, 120 ft long

Components: V

 

General

Hand outstretched in the final somatic gesture of this spell, the magic user summons forth a powerful blast of air, forceful enough to blow out unprotected flames smaller than a campfire.

Flames the size of a campfire or greater will flare back as far as [[/roll 2d6]] ft.

Even shielded flames such as lanterns have a high chance of being extinguished (10% per caster level).

 

Combat Effects

The wind is strong enough to hurl a small flying creature backwards by [[/roll 1d6*20]] ft, and will hold medium-sized creatures back from moving.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)

actions.name: (21-25) ESP - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Divination

Sphere: MU

Level: 2

Cast Time: 1

Range: 60 ft

Duration: 6 rounds

Save: None

AOE: One actor within range

Components: V

 

General

This spell allows the caster to overhear the surface thoughts of any thinking being in the spell's radial area of effect.

The caster need not be able to see the creature whose thoughts he is reading; the spell can be used to listen beyond a closed door.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell cannot penetrate more than two ft of stone or more than two inches of any metal, and it is foiled by even a thin sheet of lead.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the "ESP - Duration (C)" action

actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Evocation

Sphere: MU

Level: 2

Cast Time: 2

Range: 30 ft

Duration: 6 rounds

Save: See below

AOE: 20 ft radius spherical cloud

Components: V

[Foundry Note:  the spell NPC "Green Vapor" can be used in conjunction with this spell.  If used in an environment of natural/day light, I suggest going into the token light tab and setting the contrast all the way left to -1 so it shows better on the map.  In night settings this usually isn't necessary. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell creates a nauseating cloud of vapours to billow forth in a location chosen by the caster.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

All creatures caught within (or later entering) the noxious cloud must make saving throws.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature failing to save will be completely unable to act for [[/roll 1d4+1]] rounds, falling to the ground retching and gagging (treated as stunned).

A creature that succeeds in making the saving throw may move from within the cloud and be free of the effects after only one round of gasping fresh air (again, being treated as stunned for this round).

Even creatures that succeed in making a saving throw cannot do anything within the cloud other than to leave as fast as possible.

actions.name: (34-36) Summoning - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Conjuration/Summoning

Sphere: MU

Level: 3

Cast Time: 1

Range: 30 ft

Duration: 8 rounds

Save: None

AOE: Summoned creatures

Components: V

 

[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule to only start the duration of the spell after the monsters appear. - Ed.]

 

General

By casting this spell, the magic user conjures a monster to serve him or her as allies in combat or to perform other services. The monster appears from thin air within 1d4 rounds of the spell's completed casting.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

For more complex tasks than simple combat, the magic user must somehow have the ability to communicate these more specific commands.

 

Combat Effects

If the caster is in combat, the monster will fight on his or her behalf, attacking whatever foes he directs, or guarding him or her. 

Summon an animal—a rhino (01–25 on d%), elephant (26–50), or mouse (51–100)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Time to Arrival" action
  • Whatever animals the caster summoned, add their tokens to the scene
  • Add the animal tokens to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the autokill effect to work
  • Target the summoned tokens and click the "Summoning I - Duration Autokill" effect
    • The GM can trigger attacks through the attacks/actions on the token

actions.name: (37-46) Lightning Bolt - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Evocation

Sphere: MU

Level: 3

Cast Time: 1

Range: 100 ft

Duration: Instantaneous

Save: Half

AOE: See below

Components: V

 

General

As the caster completes this spell, he or she unleashes a bolt of lightning from the spell's point of origin, which may be as far away from the caster as the spell's maximum range.

The bolt extends in a straight line from the caster beginning at whatever point along the spell's range the caster desires, and may extend beyond the spell's range.

The length of the bolt itself is not affected by the caster's level, only the range at which the caster may cause the bolt to originate.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Creatures making successful saving throws suffer only half the indicated damage.  If they fail this saving throw their carried items are also at risk as described below.

All items not borne by someone making a personal saving throw and hit by the full force of the bolt must make item saving throws or be destroyed. The force of the bolt is often sufficient to blast doors into smouldering ruin.

 

Combat Effects

The bolt deals 6d6 damage to all creatures standing in the bolt's area of effect.

The area of effect is a concentrated blast 5 ft wide and 70 ft long

If the bolt strikes an object that does not conduct electricity, such as a stone wall, it will be deflected backward toward the caster (potentially inflicting a second shock upon those in the target area).

Note that the length of a deflected bolt is not increased; the bolt will only rebound for the distance remaining in its original area of effect.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger a saving throw (this may already have been done)
  • Click the  "Damage (Lightning Bolt)" action

actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 1

Cast Time: 1

Range: 60 ft

Duration: 6 turns

Save: Negates

AOE: One creature or object

Components: V

 

[Foundry Note: the first cast (which doesn't force a saving throw) should be used always, so that the scroll incurs a used charge.  The save in the 2nd cast (which doesn't burn charges) can be used if the spell is cast upon a creature. 

The spell doesn't specify the change in strength for creatures without a book STR score, which is most "monstrous" NPCs.  A house rule effect that simply multiplies their damage by increasing percentage based on caster level is also provided, if the GM prefers to handle the spell consequences in that fashion- Ed.]

 

General

This spell causes a creature or object to grow in size and weight. The spell increases:

  •  a creature's size and weight by 120%
  • an object's size and weight by 60%

The magic user's power limits the volume of material that he or she can enlarge; the mage can affect no more than:

  • 60 cubic ft of living matter
  • 30 cubic ft of non-living matter

The reverse of this spell is Reduce.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the spell is cast on an unwilling recipient, a successful saving throw will negate the spell, but willing recipients may choose to forgo the save.

 

Combat Effects

A normal sized person doubled in size will generally have strength of 18.
actions.name: (50-53) Enlarge - Wand
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (If cast on an actor) target an actor and click the  "Enlarge (MU L5-L9) - Duration (T)" action
    • If the actor is a non-character monster without a STR score (e.g., a MU summons a goblin and then casts Enlarge on it) then use the   "Enlarged No STR Score - Duration (T)" action instead

actions.name: (50-53) Enlarge - Wand
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 1

Cast Time: 1

Range: 30 ft

Duration: 6 turns

Save: Negates

AOE: One creature or object

Components: V

[Foundry Note: the first cast (which doesn't force a saving throw) should be used always, so that the scroll incurs a used charge.  The save in the 2nd cast (which doesn't burn charges) can be used if the spell is cast upon a creature. 

The spell doesn't specify the change in strength for creatures without a book STR score, which is most "monstrous" NPCs.  A house rule effect that simply multiplies their damage by increasing percentage based on caster level is also provided, if the GM prefers to handle the spell consequences in that fashion- Ed.]

 

General

This spell causes a creature or object to grow in size and weight. The spell increases:

  •  a creature's size and weight by 120%
  • an object's size and weight by 60%

The magic user's power limits the volume of material that he or she can enlarge; the mage can affect no more than:

  • 60 cubic ft of living matter
  • 30 cubic ft of non-living matter

The reverse of this spell is Reduce.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the spell is cast on an unwilling recipient, a successful saving throw will negate the spell, but willing recipients may choose to forgo the save.
